channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Garland Faces Tough Calls in Weighing Response to Trump Ruling
item.description: As the department decides whether to appeal the ruling on a special master, it is balancing a desire to speedily resolve the inquiry with the need to limit an expansive view of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Until the ruling, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland and his top officials had controlled the public narrative surrounding the inquiry.

item.title: A Long-Shot Push to Bar Trump From a Presidential Bid in 2024
item.description: The drive reflects concern among Democrats and anti-Trump Republicans that, despite multiple investigations and evidence of wrongdoing, the former president may make a comeback.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump is the widely presumed front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024.

item.title: F.B.I. Sought Interview With Trump Aide in Capitol Riot Case
item.description: Federal prosecutors issued a subpoena to William Russell, who served as a special assistant to the former president, and went to his home in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: William Russell, who served as a special assistant and the deputy director of advance under President Donald J. Trump, continued to work for him as a personal aide after he left office.

item.title: In Bannon Case, Manhattan D.A. Takes On Another Pardoned Trump Ally
item.description: Stephen K. Bannon will face state charges related to his role in an effort to build a border wall despite having been pardoned by former President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen K. Bannon will be the first recipient of a presidential pardon to be prosecuted in New York since a 2019 law allowing such charges.

item.title: Memphis Shooting Spree Leaves 4 Dead
item.description: The police arrested a 19-year-old who they said had carried out a string of shootings. Residents had been urged to stay indoors during the search.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Houston Cofield for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police in Memphis flooded the city on Wednesday in pursuit of a gunman who killed four people.

item.title: Myles Sanderson, Suspect in Canada Stabbings, Is Dead
item.description: After a four-day manhunt, the police arrested Myles Sanderson, a suspect in a stabbing rampage that left 10 dead in the Canadian province. He was pronounced dead at a hospital after going into “medical distress,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police took Myles Sanderson, who had been driving the white pickup truck, into custody Wednesday afternoon in Saskatchewan.

item.title: EU Leaders Say Putin’s Gas Power Is Weakening
item.description: In Germany and elsewhere, leaders are growing more confident that months of work to stockpile and line up alternate energy sources may help them blunt Russia’s weaponization of exports.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy, Erika Solomon and Anton Troianovski

item.title: In Ukraine, a Beekeeper Hunkers Down With His ‘Frontline Bees’
item.description: With nearby sunflower fields unplanted and rockets overhead, a Ukrainian’s bees ventured toward the battlefront and returned with a bumper crop.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Even as the war encroached, Petro Fedorovych, a beekeeper, stayed in his small village of Bohdanivka. “I built this house with my hands,” he said. “I will never leave.”

item.title: Biden Tries to Condemn Trumpism, Without Writing Off the G.O.P.
item.description: President Biden has taken pains to show that he understands there is a difference between what he calls extremist “MAGA Republicans” and other members of the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: “I want to be very clear up front: Not every Republican is a MAGA Republican. Not every Republican embraces that extreme ideology,” President Biden said on Monday.

item.title: California Leaders Credit Cellphone Alert for Sudden Conservation
item.description: The jarring message warned millions of residents that blackouts could occur without immediate action.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Power lines in Cathedral City, Calif., during the heat wave on Tuesday.

item.title: Official Obama Portraits Are Finally Unveiled at the White House
item.description: In a break with tradition, there was no ceremony while former President Donald J. Trump held office. President Biden unveiled the Obama portraits: his by Robert McCurdy, hers by Sharon Sprung.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:description: After an unusual delay, the official White House portraits of former President Barack Obama and first lady Michelle Obama were unveiled Wednesday at a ceremony in the East Room.

item.title: Sharon Sprung’s Painting of Michelle Obama Took 9 Months
item.description: Sharon Sprung, an instructor at the Art Students League of New York, is a realist painter of the old school.
item.dc:creator: Will Heinrich
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Sprung, who painted Michelle Obama’s official White House portrait, in her artist studio on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. What holds her interest is “the crinkle of an eye, the little noise of a lip.”

item.title: Apple Unveils New iPhone and Fitness Watch at Annual Event
item.description: The Apple Watch Ultra is aimed at endurance athletes, a market dominated by Garmin. Apple also introduced updated AirPods.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Brian X. Chen
item.media:description: From left, a new Apple Watch 8, Apple Watch Ultra and Apple Watch SE on display at Apple headquarters on Wednesday.

item.title: Frances Tiafoe Reaches US Open Semifinals With Win Over Rublev
item.description: Tiafoe backed up a win over Rafael Nadal with a quarterfinal victory over Andrey Rublev, 7-6 (3), 7-6 (0), 6-4.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Frances Tiafoe took command during tiebreakers in the first two sets.

item.title: Alcaraz Leaves It (Very, Very) Late in Defeating Sinner at U.S. Open
item.description: The Spaniard needed five sets and more than five hours to reach the semifinals in a match that ended shortly before 3 a.m. in New York.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz on Thursday after his victory over Jannik Sinner during the quarterfinal match at the U.S. Open.

item.title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Alice Coltrane
item.description: We asked writers, critics and musicians including Meshell Ndegeocello and Angel Bat Dawid to tell us what moves them in Coltrane’s spiritual jazz.
item.dc:creator: Marcus J. Moore

item.title: Do You Think Your Newfound Popularity Has Something to Do With Politics?
item.description: Everybody wants to be your email pal.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins

item.title: Pakistan’s Vulnerability to Disaster Was Through the Roof. Then Came the Floods.
item.description: The Pakistani climate scientist Fahad Saeed on why he’s scared.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: How Michigan Resisted Far Right Extremism
item.description: Michigan may hold lessons for residents of other states looking to withstand the tide of authoritarianism and violence.
item.dc:creator: Barbara McQuade
item.media:description: Militia members inside the Michigan State Capitol in 2020 protesting the extension of Gov. Gretchen Whitmer's Covid emergency stay-at-home order.

item.title: Trump Couldn’t Have Done What He Did Without States Leading the Way
item.description: What is democracy? It depends on where you stand.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall

item.title: Is the Democratic Midterm Surge Overrated? Why Republicans Can Still Win the House and Senate.
item.description: The Dobbs ruling and falling gas prices may have shifted the narrative. But the G.O.P.’s chances in the midterms still look good.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat, Kristen Soltis Anderson and Erick Erickson
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times

item.title: Education in America: What Grown-Ups Don’t Understand About School
item.description: What is school really for? Students at Oakland’s Fremont High answer this question with their cameras.
item.dc:creator: Fremont High School students

item.title: ‘Wellness’ Can Be a Trap for Moms. Here’s How to Avoid It.
item.description: Realizing that it’s not something you buy off the shelf.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: Can America’s Schoolchildren Recover From the Pandemic?
item.description: Students are struggling, and not just on standardized tests.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Bokat-Lindell
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photographs by Willie B. Thomas, Westend61 and Vergeles Andrey, via Getty Images

item.title: Many Subway Riders Gave Up on the Mask Mandate Before Hochul Did
item.description: As the governor lifted the requirement for mass transit, passengers said they were already making their own personal risk assessments.
item.dc:creator: James Barron

item.title: David Sedaris’s Diaries
item.description: The essayist talks about his book “Theft by Finding,” a selection of diary entries spanning 25 years that helped him find and shape his voice as a writer.

item.title: Let’s Talk About E.L. Doctorow’s ‘Ragtime’
item.description: Join the writer Jonathan Dee in a virtual conversation on Sept. 15 about the 1975 novel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Are there generational differences on climate in your family?
item.description: Tell us about them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Politician Arrested in Las Vegas Reporter’s Stabbing Death, Prosecutor Says
item.description: Robert Telles, the Clark County public administrator, was taken into custody in the killing of Jeff German, a reporter at The Las Vegas Review-Journal, the district attorney said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Texas Judge’s Ruling Puts Free Preventive Care in Jeopardy
item.description: A federal judge in Texas found that the Affordable Care Act’s process for determining what kinds of preventive care should be covered by insurance violates the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
United States Preventive Services Task Force
item.media:description: A ruling in Texas could jeopardize millions of Americans’ access to preventive services, including cancer screenings and drugs that prevent H.I.V. infection.

item.title: Solomon Islands’ Leader, a Friend of China, Gets an Election Delayed
item.description: The prime minister claims the country can’t afford to hold national elections next year. His opponents see a power grab linked to Beijing’s influence.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare of the Solomon Islands in 2019. He said the postponement of national elections “does not in any way inhibit or prohibit the right to vote.”

item.title: Anne Garrels, Fearless NPR Correspondent, Dies at 71
item.description: She reported on conflicts around the world and for a time was the only American broadcast journalist reporting from Baghdad during the U.S. “shock and awe” bombing campaign in 2003.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: Are Vasectomies Reversible?
item.description: If you are considering the procedure, but are worried about its permanence, here is what experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Why Is My Eyelid Twitching? Questions and Answers
item.description: And how do I get it to stop?
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Mark Elzey for The New York Times

item.title: What Should I Look for When Buying Whole Grains?
item.description: There are several reliable ways to identify whole-grain foods.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan

item.title: Is the Saturated Fat in Chocolate as Bad as the Fat in Meat?
item.description: Chocolate contains a healthier blend of fats than meats do. But don’t go overboard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Are Calcium Supplements Safe?
item.description: Kidney stones are a known risk, but studies have investigated other potential safety concerns, including an increased risk of death, cancer and heart disease.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.

item.title: No Flower Headbands at This Music Festival
item.description: Ravers donned their flimsiest finery for the Electric Zoo music festival in New York.
item.dc:creator: Shane O’Neill and Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet
